div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, APRIL 5, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of communication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency. 31-12-904

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Slightly warmer weather has prevailed since Saturday but on the whole it has been pleasant.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: RUSSIAN ROYALTIES VISIT
div.p: St. Petersburg,April 4, The Piicce and Prhiops.-. Henry of Prussia arc vi.-iting flic Tsar at Tsarskoe Solo privately. (Reuter.) .St. Petersburg, April 4. Prince and Princess Ilenty of Prussia have art i mb at Tsa'rskoe-Solo. (Ifarat.) . GRAND l)UCrIIESS SERGIUS.
The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 6.30 p.m. to-day.

div.head: Collapse of a House
div.p: A house collapsed this morning in the Attarin quarter of Alexandria, burying three persons in the ruins.

div.head: The Feldmann Case
div.p: Mr. Foldmann has been released on giving bail for L.E. 200. He has entered an appeal against the sentence.

div.head: Al hambra
div.p: The performances of Alc.van- drie en Raises arc drawing to a close, after a successful run. A new scene is to be added this evening entitled ‘‘The Laud Bank.”

div.head: Executions at Alexandria
div.p: The new execution chamber at Hadra prison has just been completed, and in' the future all executions at Alexandria will take place there.

div.head: Manoeuvres
div.p: The 3rd, 7th and 16th Battalions of Infantry, the Egyptian Cavalry, the Maxim Battery, and the pupils of the Military School will begin their annual manoeuvres in a day of two.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL
div.p: On the 1st and 2nd inst. 35 vessels passed through the Canal. 21 of these were British, 1 Austrian, 7 German, 2 French, 2 Italiau, .2 Norwegian. The receipts for the two days were frs. 779;699.59. ST. Catherine’s Cathedral at Alexandria has be'en embellished by a hue monument to the lute Bishop Gaudenzio Boufigli. The inauguration of this monument will take place on Friday next, 7 th mst., at 9 a.m.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE DANCE
div.p: The last small dance this season will take place at Ghezireh Palace to morrow evening ami promises to make agouti linish, as it tsgiveu by the special req ot many visitors at the hotel and Residents.

div.head: The Bourse Case
div.p: Hie appeal of Messrs. Bustrus Brotuors aganlst the j udgment of the Mixed Commercial Court of Alexandria in their case against the Alexandria Stockbrokers As- sociation, was to have been heard this morning Out was postponed until next IVoduoaduy. ■ Gath s Circus continues to draw large aud duiigntud audiences totue Abbfts llcimy lhcn- tie, aud the new ‘‘turns” which have been introduced are well worth seeing. To avoid the usual crush at the iuuliiiAe performances on Sunday, an extra matinee will be given on Thursday next, commencing at 4 p.m. This perioimiince .should meet with lavor among Kauiietntes, who cannot come in for the even-, lug performance.Hie appeal of Messrs. Bustrus Brotuors aganlst the j udgment of the Mixed Commercial Court of Alexandria in their case against the Alexandria Stockbrokers As- sociation, was to have been heard this morning Out was postponed until next IVoduoaduy. ■ Gath s Circus continues to draw large aud duiigntud audiences totue Abbfts llcimy lhcn- tie, aud the new ‘‘turns” which have been introduced are well worth seeing. To avoid the usual crush at the iuuliiiAe performances on Sunday, an extra matinee will be given on Thursday next, commencing at 4 p.m. This perioimiince .should meet with lavor among Kauiietntes, who cannot come in for the even-, lug performance.

div.head: GREEK INDEPENDENCE DAY
div.p: On Friday next, the anniversary ol the declaration of Gteek independence (March 25, O.S.) will be celebrated uy the Greek colonies throughout Egypt. There will a high mass at the Ortnodox Cathedral of Evaugehlmos at Alexaudria and the usual official service at St. Nicholas’s, in the Haiuzawi quarter of Cairo, which will be attended by M. Geunadis, Hellenic Diplomatic Agent aiid Consul General, aud the staff of thy Agency aud Consulate.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUSEUM
div.p: During the month of Muich, 433 persons paid for admission to the Museum, 457 to Pumpey’s Pillar, aud 836 to Kum el-Shougafa, while 1,756 persons were admitted free to the jMuseum. A comparison between,th^ hrst quarter ot this year and the same quarter ot last year shows that 232 more persons paid fur aduiissiun to the Museum this year, 729 to Pumpey’s Pillar, aud 56 to Kom el Shougafa, while 1,564 more persons were admitted tree to the Museum.

div.head: A ROYAL VISITOR.
div.p: Negotiations of considerable importance to* the commercial community of Egypt began this morning between Sir John Deuison Pen- der, K.C.M.G., vice-chairman and managing director of the Eastern. Telegraph Company, and the Egyptian Government, in regard to the reduction of the Eastern Telegraph Company’s rates for telegrams as far as Egypt is con- cerned. Sir John Denison Pender, who is accompa- nied by his wife, arrived at Port Said yesterday afternoon by the P. & 0. S.S. "Caledonia” from Marseilles and, on disembarking, pro- ceeded at once to Cairo. The negotiations will only last a day or two, and Sir John’s visit to Egypt will be of short duration. If these negotiations are brought to a suc- cessful issue, it is expected that the reductions that will ensue will be considerable. The amount of telegraphic work on the Eastern Telegraph Company’s system between Egypt and Europe has increased greatly, owing to the enormous financial and commercial deve- lopment of this country. Reductions will be welcomed by all the business community, and it is sincerely to be hoped, therefore, that the present negotiations will be brought to a satisfactory termination.

div.head: MESOPOTAMIA
div.p: jn' Jnnuary 1903 I took the discharge of Ibis Euphrates near Mosaib and found it 750 '" )u’>io lustres per Second with the gauge at 1.00 metres. The width was 250 metres, the 3.30 metres, and the velocity. .90 metres !'n“r second. By calculation I made the maximum ;,)fiischarg® 2koj00cubic metres per second and I the.minimum 250. M. Mougel informed me that the maximum discharge was 3,000 cubic . metres per second and the minimum 300. The width of the Euphrates between Feluja and Mosaib may be taken as 250 metres ; the depth at low water as 2 metres, and in flood as 5.5 inetres.- At Mosaib is a very dangerous curve on the river which needs heavy pro- tective works. If the Euphrates were to burst its banks at this curve,the heaviest inundations would eDsue,’ and the regimen of the river would be disorganised for many years. Below Mosaib is the head of the Hindia Banal. At the head of the Hindia Canal (or more properly speaking ruin) is a weir 230 metres long. The body of the weir consists of heavy blocks of limestone brought down from Hit, and thrown into the water from boats. The width of pitching, at the base is 35 metres, and at top'15 metros,, with a mean height 7.50 ^(metres above the scoured bed of the river. On this base of pitching is a masonry wall 10 ' “metres wide at bottom, 2 metres wide at top, and 2.50 metres higdi. In the middle of the weir is an opening 20 metres wide, where there is no masonry wall overlying the pitching. When I was. there in January, with 750 cubic metres per second'passing down the canal (tor the Ei.phia'.cs itsfcff below the Hindia Canal head, past Bybyloh and Hille, was discharging under 20 cnbiciuietres per secojid)jyhe head of water waa‘2.00 metres,. In high flood the head is reduced to 1.00 metre, while iu low supply it is J .30 metres. In low supply the Euphrates below the Hindia Canal head is dry for about Between the head of the Hindia Canal at Mosaib aud Sawatna, where the Hindia Canal flows back into the river after having trave-sed the Nejel swamps, the Euphrates has a length of about 240 kilometres. Iu this reach there is a fair supply iu flood, but there is no water in summer. At .the beginning of the reach the width of the river iu flood may be taken as be- tween 150 and ioo metres, while at the tail the width is, quite; insignificant; indeed the' river may be said to have ceased to exist be- fore Saw«ua is reached. The true Euphrates to-day is tho Hindia Canal. Past Babylon and Hille the river has silted up to a height of 3 or 4'metres above its ancient bed.-Babylon has known many vicissitudes, but none so severe as-the present deprivation of water,

The annual, general meeting of the Alex- andria Cricket Club was held at H.B.M.’s Consulate on March 29. The chair was taken by Mr. Gould. The accounts for 1904 were presented by the honorary treasurer, Mr. Marsden, and -passed; , J, Mr. H. B. Carver arid Mr. H. P. Carver wefe elected, respectively, captain and vice- iiitaiu for the current year, and’ Messrs. K. P. 3>l$y, P. W,.Carver, SI Dorling, F. G. Free- * j. C. Macaulay, R. B. McLean, T, H. arsden, and H. Thomas were re-elected as 4 caabers of the Committee. PbH meeting c m tinned the resolution pa'sed ?'Vie extraordinary general meeting of 4§rist 29; 1904, to the effect that the annual ' diS^iptioo of members should be raised to .. was also decided that the annual sub- j g^ion payable by the staff of the Eastern * ’ygraph Co, should be £18, and that the ouuscription-of life members should be raised fronis£10 t0s£15. ) It was decided that members using the squash rAcquet courts should be allowed to make one annual payment instead of a pay- ment per day or per game, and that the Hint of such charge should be determined . vote of thanks to the chairman closed the , jeedings. / Tlie committee met on April 3, and re-elect- ed Mr. Marsden as honorary treasurer and Mr. Freeman honorary secretary. Mr. K. L. Macaulay and Mr. Q-. J. Finney were appoint- ed stewards of the racquet courts and tenuis courts respectively. The annual charge for members using-fhe racquet courts was fixed at 75 piastres tariff, but for this year (May to December) at 60 piastres tariff only. The alter- native daily, charge was fixed at 5 piastres tariff. ., Cricket practice will bo resumed after the 12th instant. The day fixed for the opening of*the racquet courts will be announced sub- sequently.

div.head: THE DAWN OF EGYPTIAN TRADE
div.p: Archaeological research among the ruins ol the cities of the old world has thrown a new and unexpected light upon the beginnings of trade and commerce. There is a yast pre- historic veldt of time stretching far beyond tho threshold of history; a silent age, which has'bequeathed to us no written story, but finds its record in the conteqts of tombs and graves of the Nile valley or the deepest strata of the mounds of Chaldea and Susiannia. What a record of commercial activity is preserved to us by a small fragment, of jade, telling of a, weary caravan journey from the heart of Asia; while the fragments of a carved rhinoceros horn, found with pieces of ivory or ebony, in the dynasty tombs at Nagada and Abydos first show that even at that remote period, some five thousand years before the Christian era, the Egyptian had penetrated into the heart of the Dark Continent. It is this opening up of Africa which forms one of the most interesting chapters in the history of trade and commerce, and in which we find a solution of .the problem of ancient gold-working in South Africa.

div.head: THE NILE VALLEY
div.p: were a peaceful race, possessing no aggressive- ambition, but contented to hold their own, to a certain extent maintaining a conservative policy. Still, however,. the exigencies of civili- sation produced certain wants which could only be met by trade and commerce. To the Nile Valley there were two channels of entrance—a southern by the main waterway of the Nile, an eastern chiefly by the isthmus of Suez, and the long narrow valley leading to the shores of the Red Sea. The trade with the Upper Nile regions began in prehistoric times, as shown by the largo quantities of ivory. and ebony found' in the tombs of the archaic and early dynastic periods. One curious feature of this trade was the importation of dwarfs or pigmies.. The skeletons and funeral state of these little men have been found in the The importation of these little men was par- tially connected with religion, for they are ' spoken of as “ the pigmies that' danced before the God,” probably the God Bes, the God of laughter and dancing, the God with- the mask, from whom the Greeks derived their God of Comedy. They become, however, pets, and are curiously enough usually named, in a sarcastic vein, no doubt, Nefer “beauty.” In the second and sixth dynasties we have records of such importations. The most important record of this up-Nile trade is found in a curious papyrus of the time of the Twelfth dynasty, about B.C. 2500;' which records the adventures of a trader who passed up the Nile far into the Dark Continent, when he was shipwrecked.

RUSSELL KERR, Chartered Accountants, Cairo and Alexandria. MANAGERS. SECRETARIES, AND OFFICE IN LONDON. MACK PALMER, Palmerston House, Old Broad Street, E.C. This Company is formed for the purpose of carrying on the business ot an Investment,Exploration,and Development Company, especially in Bgypt and the Spudan. For aome jreare private Syndicates have been exploring concessions granted by the Egyptian and Soudan Governments with .very satisfactory results; districts previously unexplored Have been opened np, and laud hitherto of little value is now steadily idipioring in price, and is in great demand. The irrigation and reclamation schemes projected are likely to still further inorease the investment for kujj and oonoessions. ^ In view of the above, it is proposed that this Company shall .pay speoial attention to business conneoted with land development, irrigation schemes, and reclamation works. A. \ It is generally admitted that the many industries of Egypt, under the careful snpervision of the Government, are now making steady progress. It is intended to act as financial agents in London, Paris and elsewhere for land .development, mining and other oompaniae) and it is anticipated that considerable profit will result from this source. In view of the increasing interest of French Investors in Egyptian Securities, it is proposed to open a Branch Offioe in Pari* at an ' early date. As the success of Company of this nature is to a large extent dependent upon a thorough knowledge of looal nnnilitinn. it j, extremely satisfactory to have secured the services, as Direotor and Agent-Gsneral in Egypt, of Mr. Hooker, late General Manager of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, formerly Direotor-General of the Egyptian Government Salt Department in Egypt; his knowledge of the oonntry and looal) business conditions is probably unequalled. Mr. Hooker has consented to apt for a period of throe years, at a salary of £1,000 per annum, with .a farther remuneration equal to 5 per oonk of the net profits id each year available for distribution among the shareholders (whether distnbuted! or not) in excess of an amount equal to £10 per conti on the capital paid up on the Shares of the Company for the time being issued. 100,000 shares’forming part of the present issue have been underwritten at a commission of 3 per oeuL, with an qver^idyy commission of 1 per oent which will be paid by the Company. The Directors are interested as sub-un lerwriters, and each will reoeive the 4 per cent, on tho number of shpaae undenrritteo- by him as follows: — Sir William F.Haynes Smith, 2,006 Shares; Major ViUiera, 10,000 Shares; A.H. Hooker, 5,000 Shares; F. R*e*ellRpbert*,.5,000 Shares; J.W. Matthews, 5,000 Shares; H.E. Crookabank Pacha, 500 Shares. The preliminary expenses, including registration foes and stamp doty, legal expenses and broken’ fees, the oost of . advertising and issuing this Prospectus, down to and including the allotment other than the underwriting commission and brokerage, are estimated at £4,000, which will be paid by the Company. jromotionmioney has been or will be paid. ^ The Company' W1 pay a brokerage of 3d. per shares to Bankere on£ll shares applied for and allotted to the public on forma bearing the Banker’s and Broker's stamn.
